sect1.title: DICTIONARY DICTIONARY

row.entry: The name of the DICTIONARY for later use in other definitions.
The name of a DATASET or recordset from which to derive the DICTIONARY. This may be defined inline (similar to an inline DATASET).
The (usually inline) RECORD structure defining the layout of the fields. This may use the "results in" operator (=>) to indicate payload fields.

sect1.para: The DICTIONARY declaration defines a set of unique records indexed by the fields named in the struct that appear before the "results in" operator (=>), while any subsequent fields are payload fields. This is similar to the payload version of an INDEX. You may access individual records in the DICTIONARY by indexing into it using square brackets ( [ ] ) containing the key field values that identify the record to reference.

sect2.title: DICTIONARY Definition
sect2.para: The first form of DICTIONARY allows you to efficiently check whether a particular data value is in a list (using the IN operator), or to simply map data. It is similar to a LOOKUP JOIN that can be used in any context. The DICTIONARY maps each unique value o

The struct parameter described above is a RECORD structure, usually defined inline, which specifies the field layout, similar to the RECORD structure parameter of a TABLE function. The first field(s) define the key field(s) used to search the DICTIONARY. The "results in" operator(=>) delimits key fields from the payload fields. The payload may specify individual fields or may use the name of the dataset to payload all the non-key fields.

sect2.title: DICTIONARY as a Value Type
sect2.para: The second form of DICTIONARY is a value type with the struct parameter specifying the structure of the data. This data type usage allows you to specify a DICTIONARY as a child dataset, similar to the way DATASET may be used to define a child dataset. This may also be used to pass a DICTIONARY as a parameter.
